relations.target: buzz=01262688-n (a confusion of activity and gossip; \""the buzz of excitement was so great that a formal denial was issued\"");07392834-n (sound of rapid vibration; \""the buzz of a bumble bee\"");00793966-v (call with a buzzer; \""he buzzed the servant\"");01928220-v (fly low; \""Planes buzzed the crowds in the square\"");02186555-v (make a buzzing sound; \""bees were buzzing around the hive\"");02712465-v (be noisy with activity; \""This office is buzzing with activity\""

bring down=00430013-v (cut down on; make a reduction in; \""reduce your daily fat intake\""; \""The employer wants to cut back health benefits\"");00750288-v (impose something unpleasant; \""The principal visited his rage on the students\"");01834249-v (cause to be enthusiastic; \""Her playing brought down the house\"");01977139-v (move something or somebody to a lower position; \""take down the vase from the shelf\"");01985050-v (cause to come to the ground; \""the pilot managed to land the airplane safely\"");02407551-v (cause the downfall of; of rulers; \""The Czar was overthrown\""; \""subvert the ruling class\""

senses.definition: Something or someone that spoils an otherwise enjoyable event.<!-- verbose; extraneous material or material that belongs elsewhere: Initially, the term referred to a rapid bring down from an alcohol or drug-induced buzz. However, the term has moved into broader culture. For example, "The meeting was going great until our boss got up on stage and let the air out. What a '''buzzkill'''!"--&gt
